fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) implies (2): Given an index set I and a function A with \mathsf {dom}(I). Consider the function A' defined by A'_{i} = (A_{i},i). Note that there is an evident surjection r\colon \bigcup _{i \in I}A'_{i}\to I that maps each (A_{i},i) to the index i. This surjection admits a section s\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A'_{i}. Then we can define the required choice function c\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A_{i} by c(i) = \pi _{1} \circ s(i).

(2) implies (3): Let A be a non-empty set. Set I := \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}. Consider the identity function B_{i} := i. Then there is a choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to \bigcup _{i \in I} B_{i}. Note that \bigcup _{i \in I} B_{i} = A so this is the required choice function.

(3) implies (4): Let F be a family of non-empty and pairwise disjoint family of sets. Observe that F \subseteq \mathcal {P}(\bigcup F) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}. Thus, we can acquire the required choice function by restricting the choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(\bigcup F) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to \bigcup F.

(4) implies AC: Let F be a family of non-empty sets. Consider the family F' := {\mathopen {}\{A \times {\mathopen {}\{A\}\mathclose {}}\colon A \in F\}\mathclose {}}. By replacement, this is a set. In particular, it consists of non-empty and pairwise disjoint sets. Thus, there is a choice function c'\colon F'\to \bigcup F'. Then we define the required choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F by c(A) = \pi _{1} \circ c'(A \times {\mathopen {}\{A\}\mathclose {}}).
The following statements are equivalent to the axiom of choice.

fr:ol.fr:li: Let I be a set and A be a function with \mathsf {dom}(A) = I such that A_{i} \neq \varnothing for all i \in I. Then there is a function c\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A_{i} such that c(i) \in A_{i} for all i \in I.
For any non-empty set A, there is a choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to A such that c(x) \in x for all non-empty x \subseteq A.
For any family F of non-empty and pairwise disjoint sets, there is a choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F such that c(x) \in x for all x \in F.
